bestBHT.bht: At their meal, the Lord took on the role of the master of the house, breaking the bread in a way that would open their eyes to recognize Him. This act startled them as a stranger was taking the place of honor at their table. As He blessed and broke the bread, their eyes were suddenly opened. It was during this ordinary meal that the disciples were able to see Jesus, learning important lessons that would later apply to the Lord's Supper.

Henry Alford: I believe that there was something in the manner of His breaking the bread, and helping and giving it to them, which was his own appointed means of opening their eyes to the recognition of Him.
The Lord at their meal takes on Him the office of the master of the house...and as the Jewish rule was, that 'three eating together were bound to give thanks,' He fulfils this duty.

In doing so, perhaps the well-known manner of His taking bread, &c., perhaps the marks of the nails in His hands, then first noticed, or these together, as secondary means,—but certainly His own will and permission to be seen by them, opened their eyes to know Him.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The stranger first startles them by taking the place of master at their own table.
Albert Barnes: Sat at meat" - Reclined at the table, or while he was at supper.
He took bread and blessed it..." - This was the office of the master of a feast, and perhaps this first attracted particularly their attention.

This was not a 'sacramental,' but a common supper; yet our Saviour sought a blessing on the food, and thus set an example to all his followers to acknowledge God in their daily gifts, and to seek his benediction in all their enjoyments.
Marvin Vincent: A very beautiful use of the imperfect, indicating that while he was in the act of distributing they recognized him.
He blessed, and having broken, was giving it to them, when, in an instant, their eyes were opened.
John Calvin: Christ gave the bread, not as an ordinary meal, but as the sacred symbol of his body.
The Lord was at length recognized in the spiritual mirror of the Lord’s Supper; for the disciples did not know him, when they beheld him with the bodily eyes.
Whenever we eat bread, [let us] offer thanksgiving to the Author of life, — an action which will distinguish us from irreligious men.
Philip Schaff: He took the bread. In so doing He assumed the duty of the master of the house.
The meal was an ordinary one, and in no sense a celebration of the Lord’s Supper, although it teaches lessons appropriate to that ordinance.
The more exact grouping is: 'taking the bread, He blessed, and breaking it, He gave to them.'
Archibald T. Robertson: Luke's common idiom as in verses Luke 24:4; Luke 24:15." (14 words)
Note first aorist passive infinitive (on the reclining as to him)." (13 words)
Imperfect, inchoative idea, began to give to them, in contrast with the preceding aorist (punctiliar) participles." (19 words)
John Gill: He took bread and blessed it, and brake, and gave to them; as if he was the master of the house.
When he was both a guest, and a stranger, and as he used to do at common meals, when he ate with his disciples.
Being three at least, Christ blessed bread for them all.
John Wesley: He took the bread, and blessed, and brake — Just in the same manner as when ho instituted his last supper.

bhtAttempts.bht: At their meal, the Lord took on the role of the master of the house, breaking the bread in a way that would open their eyes to recognize Him. This act startled them, as a stranger was taking the place of honor at their table. As He blessed and broke the bread, their eyes were suddenly opened and they recognized Him. This recognition happened in an instant, while He was still giving them the bread. It was during this ordinary meal that the disciples were able to see Jesus, not yet understanding the spiritual significance of the Lord's Supper, but learning important lessons that would later apply to that sacred ordinance.

At their meal, the Lord took on the role of the master of the house, breaking the bread in a way that would open their eyes to recognize Him. This act startled them as a stranger was taking the place of honor at their table. As He blessed and broke the bread, their eyes were suddenly opened. It was during this ordinary meal that the disciples were able to see Jesus, learning important lessons that would later apply to the Lord's Supper.

During a meal, the Lord acted as the master, breaking the bread in a manner that would open their eyes to recognize Him. Their initial surprise stemmed from a stranger assuming the position of authority at the table. As He blessed and distributed the bread, their eyes were immediately opened. This moment of revelation occurred while He was still in the process of giving them the bread. Through this ordinary meal, the disciples gained valuable insights that would later be applicable to the sacred act of the Lord's Supper.

At their meal, the Lord took on the role of the master of the house, breaking the bread in a way that would open their eyes to recognize Him. This act startled them as a stranger was taking the place of honor at their own table. While He was giving them the bread, in an instant, their eyes were opened. This ordinary meal served as a significant moment of revelation for the disciples, providing important lessons for the future observance of the Lord's Supper.

During their meal, the Lord surprised the disciples by assuming the role of the master and breaking the bread. His actions, along with possibly the marks of the nails in His hands, led to their recognition of Him. In an instant, their eyes were opened as He blessed and distributed the bread. This ordinary meal served as a powerful moment of revelation, prefiguring the future observance of the Lord's Supper and teaching important lessons about acknowledging God in daily gifts.
